Law of Composition

A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
Dedekind Domain

A Dedekind domain is an integral domain in which the theorem on unique prime factorization holds for ideals. It is a nonzero ring without nontrivial zero divisors, and Dedekind's theorem on unique prime factorization for ideals is applicable.
Division Ring
A ring R is called a division ring or a skew field if R is not the zero ring and every nonzero element of R is a unit (R* = R - {0}).
Product of Ideals

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Kernel of a Ring Homomorphism
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The kernel of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$, is defined as $\{a \in R ; \varphi(a)=0\}$, which is an ideal in $R$.
Prime Element

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
Torsion element
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.
Integral Element over a Ring

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.
Orbit
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
Sign or Signature of a Permutation

The sign or signature of a permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$, denoted as $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$, is defined by the product $\prod_{i<j} \frac{\pi(i)-\pi(j)}{i-j}$. The sign can only assume the values 1 and -1. If $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$ is positive, $\pi$ is called an even permutation, and an odd permutation otherwise.
Image of Map
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A Dedekind domain is defined as an integral domain, which is a type of ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what an integral domain is, and subsequently, what a Dedekind domain is.
The product of ideals is defined in terms of ideals in a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what ideals are, and subsequently, what the product of ideals is.

The kernel of a ring homomorphism is defined as an ideal in a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring homomorphism and an ideal are, and subsequently, what the kernel of a ring homomorphism is.

A prime element is defined in a unique factorization domain, which is a type of integral domain, and hence a type of ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a unique factorization domain is, and subsequently, what a prime element is.
A torsion element is defined in the context of an A-module. Therefore, the concept of a module must be defined to understand what a torsion element is.

An integral element over a ring is defined with respect to a ring homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring homomorphism is, and subsequently, what an integral element over a ring is.

A splitting field of a polynomial is defined over its prime subfield, which is a type of field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what a prime subfield is, and subsequently, what a splitting field is.

The orbit of a point under a group action is defined in terms of the action of a group on a set. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined to understand what a group action is, and subsequently, what an orbit is.

The sign or signature of a permutation is defined in terms of the elements of a permutation group. Therefore, the concept of a permutation group must be defined to understand what a permutation is, and subsequently, what the sign or signature of a permutation is.
The image of a map is defined in terms of a function. Therefore, the concept of a function must be defined to understand what the image of a map is.
